When engineers or builders plan to build something, the first and the main issue they concern about is safety. That is why on ships, in submarines (where I worked for more than 30 years), at factories and so on, you can see the sign "Safety First!" And there always is a technical commission that decides if a vehicle, building or whatever complies with safety rules. If not, none of a technical commission will sign documents allowing this vehicle or whatever to be used as a working one. Safety first! Anything else doesn't matter. American Institute of Ladders  states: "Always maintain a 3-point (two hands and a foot, or two feet and a hand) contact on the ladder when climbing. Keep your body near the middle of the step and always face the ladder while climbing." None of a working vehicle can be allowed to work if there are such gross violations of safety rules. Such a ridiculous ladder was made intentionally so that people when they see how easy astronauts get the ladder at 1/6 G in the movie can believe that the movie is going on on the Moon. If you are wearing rubber gloves and a space suit highly pressurised in vacuum, you cannot grab firmly onto the ladder. You cannot raise you foot up 75 centimetres, for even without a spacesuit one cannot do that. Yes, you can jump, however, can there be 100% guarantee that you can do it without damaging your suit or your breathing apparatus. A vehicle with one way ladder can be used only as a movie props. Anyone who is familiar with ships, submarines, airplanes and building sites will understand me. All the other will continue to believe that a chicken house with a ladder that only chickens can climb can work on the Moon and be operated by people.

What always bothered me about "That's one small step for man, one giant leap for mankind" is that it doesn't make sense. What's with 'man' and 'mankind'? They mean the same thing. The explanation is that WHAT NEIL ARMSTRONG ACTUALLY SAID WAS, "THAT'S ONE SMALL STEP FOR [A] MAN, ONE GIANT LEAP FOR MANKIND"! The static in the transmission covers up the "A"! He said multiple times in interviews that he thought he said the 'a' but everyone decided it was such a momentous event that they weren't going to criticize him for the small slip-up. With the 'a' the sentence makes complete sense: 'a man' means himself, Neil Armstrong. The transmission has been closely analyzed and while they can't say it was there for sure, you can't rule it out either. Regardless, everyone quotes it without the 'a' so the sentence will continue to be somewhat meaningless for the rest of time. It would be big improvement if people would put in '[a]' which is correct according to the man who said it and the brackets mean that it's a correction the speaker meant to say.

So I know the temperatures on the moon don't square with the traditional materials used for rope making, but why not use a rope-type ladder , or even just a hoisting-cable that wouldn't rely on footing for assent and grasping for stability. I also know the moon's gravity isn't so low as to invoke cartoons walking on their fingertips, but it seems like in low-g environments it seems like you'd want footing for stability, and grasping for assent. Which is more what one experiences while rope-climbing, or cargo-net climbing, and less like ladder or step climbing. This kind of rigging would also be adjustable to multiple landing inclinations and conditions. Also with such a construct, the emergency backup plan of the second astronaut attempting rescue & pulling you back aboard if you are incapacitated uses the exact same equipment. (Because good luck getting an astronaut to fireman carry another one up and down a ladder in those big fat bolted-on spacesuits even in low gravity. They were practically so top-heavy they were trip-falling even without carrying one another. So if one miscalculated his strength or lost balance while attempting to carry another on board the incapacitated astronaut becomes an accidental battle-ram against a craft so fragile they were afraid they were going to kick a hole in it whenever they fall asleep! So it seems way better to tie-up a distressed astronaut and pull them back aboard after climbing up ahead, especially if its doubtful if the ladder system could carry two astronauts at the same time if the weight-saving design constraints were limited to one at a time procedure, and you can only do something like that with a rigging type for egress and ingress.)

I think if we had used the lamb system for many dozens of manned trips to the moon instead of the handful we had, some of it's speedy design concessions to get us to the moon first would have likely been some of the very same things that got someone killed on the moon. An increasing awareness of the flaws in that system, combined with an increasing awareness of just how dangerous the environment of space was beyond earth's magnetosphere, & just how lucky many of the Apollo missions were in the estimation of the insiders working on the program contributed to the cancelation of the American moon program, every bit as much as the Soviet withdraw from its lunar ambitions, and later its economic/political collapse, because Uncle Sam doesn't really want a system that relies too much on skill of the best of the best on the luckiest days of their lives, it wants systems that it can deploy at increasing scale with increasing frequency at reliable performance metrics across battalions made of people of average luck, and adequate skill because its along those later parameters it can run projections on its strategic interests, militarily, economically, and so on. Anything that stays at 2 failures in 100 is going to remain only an experimental level of interests gaining and loosing funding on the ever changing political whims of congress. Ideally, what they want are failure rates that are statically negligible which is much less than 1 percent of the time. Neither the Apollo or the Shuttle program managed this, but whichever system is the first to break from that pattern in a big way is going to be the one that resets the pace of space exploration for humanity.

I'm not NASA level by any stretch, but I am a mechanical engineer, so here's my take FWIW. A hinged ladder would still have failed if the feet penetrated as much as anticipated. You would not have been able to unfold the ladder and it would now have to contend with bending forces it was not designed for when the astronauts stepped on it. The picture of the russian lander there looks orders of magnitude heavier than the apollo lander, so don't forget everything on the apollo was engineered to just about do a job and not be any heavier than needed. The russian lander was never tested of course.
A telescoping ladder, with adjustable length between each rung, would have worked, though of course that's now more to go wrong and muscle memory from training could lead to incidents with the astronauts using it. Another option would be a solid, set length ladder that could be slid down the leg in runners as needed, and additional rung sections stored inside the LEM and bolted into place as needed upon exit. Again though, its possible additional weight. Did the ladder design remain the same after Apollo 11, or get changed once they knew how far it would penetrate?

When I was in USAF I maintained the HF Receiver Antennas for the Minuteman Missile System at Whiteman AFB. There were five “disposable” antennas at each of the 15 Launch control centers. They were basically 30 ft tall steel pipes filled with 300 PSI nitrogen. They were bolted down to the bottom of individual underground silos. To raise one out of the ground, a shape charge cut instantaneously completely around the pipe where they were bolted down. The 300 PSI launched them upward like a rocket. A crushable honey-cone ring slowed the “rocket” down and locked it in the erected position.

I think you should mention that Armstrong's very soft landing was actually a mistake. For reasons unknown, he didn't stop the engine at Aldrin's call of "contact" and flew powered all the way to the surface. Visibility in the last moments was unexpectedly obstructed by the dust cloud, so that neither man could see the surface, and Armstrong may not have heard the "contact" call. Landing this way worked out fine, but it was not the intended method and almost certainly not Armstong's intention.

Hey Tim,
You should see if you can find any white papers about the shock absorbing properties of the lunar regolith. Intuitively, the lack of weathering and atmospheric pressure is going to limit compaction. However, moon quakes are a thing. Processes on earth such as liquefaction do cause materials to intersperse and compact. We've recorded seismic lunar activity on human timescales. The lunar regolith has experienced eons of time for seismic activity to affect the surface materials. Obviously the topmost surface is light and fluffy as can be seen with the footprints, but for the surface to absorb the forces of such a large mass like a lander, I'm curious, academically, what other aspects and physics are involved.
